Windows Forms Quick Tip: Use your Tag property!

Posted by paullaudeman on May 13, 2005

A question I frequently come across is how to add some type of context information to UI controls in a Windows Forms project. For instance, you might have a textbox where you want to revert to the original value if a user decides to cancel edits, you could store the original value in the Tag property and pull that out when needed (if you’re not using data binding). Another example might be if you have a TreeView control and need to add information about the nodes to help perform some action when a user clicks on a node.


In either case, and many more, you should consider using the Tag property of the Control object. As you know, all Windows Forms controls (and even Forms!) inherit from the Control class which offers the Tag property. Since the Tag property is of type Object, this means that you can use it to store anything you want! You could use it to store a string, an array, a full blown class, etc., depending on your needs.


For bonus points, consider extending your Control and creating your own strongly typed properties. Just as the “Tag” property is available to you, you can create your own properties on your derived control that are strongly typed and easier to manage. Thanks to my readers for suggesting this alternative!

This entry was posted in Windows Forms. Bookmark the permalink. Follow any comments here with the RSS feed for this post.

6 Responses to Windows Forms Quick Tip: Use your Tag property!

  1. paul.laudeman says:
    May 16, 2005 at 7:26 pm

    Sure, it might have been put there for the VB6 folks, but sometimes it is more than adequate to use, with the caveats stated by others. The other suggested approach (which is just as valid) is to create your own specialized control class with a strongly typed property. I’m not sure I buy into the argument that it is all bad to use it at all, I just suggest that it is a quick alternative to creating a more specialized implementation.

  2. Dave says:
    May 16, 2005 at 4:27 pm

    Don’t you think Tag is simply there for VB6 folks? It is pretty darn lame nowadays.

  3. JosephCooney says:
    May 14, 2005 at 10:38 am

    I’m not a fan of using the Tag property, and like Jordan prefer to sub-class. The Tag is not a strongly typed way of doing things, and is not a very explicit way of doing things. You use the Tag for X. Bob starts using the tag for Y and when Bob starts working on your section of the project things go haywire.

  4. paul.laudeman says:
    May 13, 2005 at 7:14 pm

    Jordan — I believe you are right — those beta 1.0 days were so long ago!

    Your suggestion about using inheritance to create even more specialized control is something that I do all the time, too, especially with the most common UI controls to help extend base functionality.

  5. Jordan says:
    May 13, 2005 at 3:57 pm

    My preference is to create a new control which inherits from the control in question. Then you can add tons of new properties, and aren’t locked in to just one extended property.

    In fact, I think this is how MS originally intended it too, because they left the TAG property out until the final release of the dotnet framework as I recall.

    Jordan.

  6. Dave Donaldson says:
    May 13, 2005 at 1:54 pm

    Yep, you’re dead on. I use the Tag property quite a bit, especially for unique identification purposes amongst several controls, forms, etc. Very handy.
